Mar 06, 2018( Broadband TV News: http://www.broadbandtvnews.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://i2.wp.com/www.broadbandtvnews.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Michael-Powell-e1520338246386.jpg?ssl=1'We should start regulating the big tech companies,' said Michael K. Powell, president and CEO NCTA, 'We should reject the fairy tale stories of 'do no evil'.' In an aggressive speech at the Cable Congress in Dublin he called for fairer regulation of the internet - not just focusing on network companies but including the giant tech companies . The power of the new tech companies such as Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google is enormous. They are not competing in the market, 'they are the market', as The Economist wrote. When a competitor shows up, they just buy it. These companies have a market cap of $2.8 trillion, the GDP of France, while enjoying a light regulatory touch. 'We do need to start policing their behaviour, they have become too large and too indipensible not to do anything. Only they can address the issues around election fraud and sexual exploitation, while privacy remains an issue that they will not fix from within.

urn:contentItem:5XWR-WX41-F00C-628K-00000-00NDIC: Understanding consumer protection in the digital age2020-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisNDIC: Understanding consumer protection in the digital age

Consumer protection and the role of the financial regulators was the focus of the NDIC annual FICAN conference held in Yola, the Adamawa State capital, from 10-12 December 2019. The topic could not have been more apt than now when there is a renewed commitment by regulators to neutralize the efforts of criminals to undermine consumers of digital financial services (DFS) by exploiting the latter's vulnerabilities in an increasingly digital and data-driven world. There is a Consumer Protection Department at CBN and two consumer desks at the NDIC, which shows a national commitment to provide safety nets to consumers.

Digital financial services (DFS) have been defined as financial operations using digital technology, including electronic money, mobile financial services, online financial services, i-teller and branchless banking, whether through a bank or non-bank institutions. It can encompass various monetary transactions such as depositing, withdrawing, sending and receiving money, as well as other financial products and services including payment, credit, saving, pensions and insurance.

DFS can also include non-transactional services, such as viewing personal financial information through digital devices. It is only as recently as 2018 that the G20 countries came up with a non-binding policy guidelines on financial consumer protection in the digital age, indicating the fact that regulation in this sector is just emerging.

The Nigeria Deposit Insurance Corporation (NDIC) is aware of the paucity of regulatory policy initiatives in this sector and is therefore providing a platform for stakeholders in the nation's financial sector to rub minds on how to better the economy and protect the consumer. This is the essence of the Financial Correspondents Association of Nigeria (FICAN) workshop, sponsored by Nigeria Deposit Insurance Corporation (NDIC) annually.

The 16th edition of NDIC/FICAN workshop was refreshingly intellectual and went a long way in adding value to the general public's financial literacy in the country. The high points of the annual workshop's brilliant discussions around developments in the financial sector focused attention on the protection of the consumer by the financial regulators.

The MD/CEO of NDIC, Alhaji Umaru Ibrahim, was ably represented at the occasion because of the value he put on promoting financial literacy and his commitment to financial journalism practice. It is not surprising that the MD declared in his opening remarks that "with the recourse to technology and Fintechs, the entire dynamics of banking has been altered to such an extent that it poses serious challenges for both operators and regulators".

He also made it clear that "it was in recognition of what the future is likely to portend for the banking industry that for this year's workshop is dedicated to providing insight." Digital Financial Services (DFS) have both tremendous benefits and equally terrible risks as captured by the study conducted by the G20/OECD in 2018. A few of the benefits include: The digitalisation of finance offers the opportunity to achieve broad-based financial inclusion by extending the availability and penetration of financial services and by reducing the costs of providing financial services to the underserved population as we have seen with mobile banking.

New financial technologies can help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access alternative funding sources for supporting their cash flow and risk capital needs. DFS are offering more convenient, faster, secure and cheaper transactions.

This has positive implications in both advanced and emerging economies for businesses and consumers, both established users of financial products and the newly financially included. The latter in particular stand to benefit from a digital environment even in the absence of physical branches or agents provided appropriate security measures and consumer precautions are in place to avoid fraudulent transactions and other risks.

The digital revolution goes hand-in-hand with new providers entering the market and offering financial services directly to individuals through digital channels can have an impact on the level of competition in the financial market and contribute to lower costs, and offer an improved experience to financial consumers. Examples here include what we are witnessing in Nigeria in the urban transportation sector more digital platforms for moving around using taxis and the popular tricycle is being introduced into the market.

These are indeed interesting developments that capture one's imagination, courtesy of digital financial revolution unfolding before our eyes. The associated risks are also awesome categorized as follows: Market-driven: this can include misuse of unfamiliar (or new types of) products to uninformed consumers new types of fraud, often taking advantage of consumers' uncertainty in the digital environment a lack of security, privacy and confidentiality of data inappropriate or excessive use of digital profiling to identify potential customers and exclude unwanted groups Regulation and supervision driven: this can encompass uneven levels of protection within (e.

. inadequate disclosure and redress mechanisms) and across countries (e.

. variety of providers, cross border selling, regulatory arbitrage) consideration of data protection issues a lack of coordination among authorities for example with respect to new types of digital financial services.

Consumer-driven: the growing digitalisation of daily life and of financial decisions is not necessarily matched by increasing digital and financial literacy levels. Technology-driven: the increasing use of algorithms, which can affect decisions about credit, insurance or investments and can lead to denied access to certain services or inappropriate charges based on inaccurate or wrong correlations made without human interpretation unreliability of mobile networks and digital finance platforms may lead to inability to carry out transactions, inaccessibility of funds or cybersecurity risks.

Each of the 5 papers presented did justice to the topic. Let us glance at them briefly.

Dr. K.

S.Katata of the Research, Policy and International Relations of the NDIC presented two papers onFintech and Future of Banking and Key Attributes and Bank Failure Resolution Option.

The former paper surmised that Fintech firms and big tech organizations are capturing more and more of the banking value chain, providing services such as payments, checking and even savings accounts that could erode much of the traditional bank revenues in the foreseeable future. He demonstrated how these new entrants pose a threat to banks by raising service expectations and coming between banks and their customers.

He also cautioned traditional banks that their response should go far beyond closing branches, improving online and mobile banking offerings or making current products and services "more digital." Instead, he advised banks to move further into the daily lives of customers, providing assistance before, during and after the financial transaction.

He agreed with the forecast by PwC that to be successful as a Bank in 2030, the bank of the future will need to embrace emerging technology remain flexible to adopt evolving business models, and put customers at the center of every strategy. The second paper discussed the objectives of effective resolution of banks that fell into deep crisis and the various legal frameworks and the tools developed over the years to help minimize risks of bank failures within Nigeria and the international best practices.

For instance, he listed the key objectives of the efforts to protect depositors to included: minimise adverse effects on banking and financial system stability ensure continuity of basic banking functions minimise reliance on public sector support and protect client funds and assets Abdulhamid Aliyu of the Bank Examination Department of the NDIC presented Emerging Issues in the banking regulation and supervision. He identified six emerging issues of concern to banking regulators as Defaults from traditional income haven of banks, namely oil and gas Derivatives defaults, especially on currency swap Disruptive technology Entry of Big Tech firms like Google, Amazon and Apple into the financial services will post a fin stability risk Cyber-crime and Insufficient expertise in the assessment of IFRS 9 implementation may affect the level of compliance and enforcement.

The paper went on to give possible mitigating steps as Continue proactive measures to ensure financial system stability Investment in disruptive technology Core investment in the training and re-training of bankers and regulators Regulators will need new laws to enable a level plain field with smaller tech firms and banks and more investment in Cybersecurity. S.

A. Oluyemi of Communication and Public Affairs Department of the NDIC presented a paper on The Role of Banks in Financial Literacy and Inclusion.

His paper dwelt on the achievements and challenges of the National Financial Inclusion Strategy (NFIS). He concluded that enhanced financial literacy is the key to financial inclusion and financial inclusion, consumer protection and financial literacy complement each other.

The three formed the bedrock of the NFIS. The NFIS is essential to increase financial inclusion and consumers have to gain the knowledge, skills and confidence they need to make good financial decisions and the banking industry is necessary and supportive of the strategy's goals.

Finally, the paper titled Consumer Protection in the Financial System was delivered by S.K.

Salam-Alada of the Consumer Protection Department of the CBN. The paper concluded that consumer protection is critical in all that the financial system gamut is out to achieve in guaranteeing the future economic and social well-being of Nigeria through: promoting savings culture and entrepreneurship poverty reduction improved income-facilitating development engendering consumers' confidence addressing socio-economic challenges and ultimately ensuring financial system stability, sustainable economic growth and national development.

NDIC has come of age, having celebrated its 30 years of existence this year. It has every reason to celebrate its monumental achievements in carrying out its core mandate of minimizing risk through deposit insurance system (DIS) in our financial system.

Of the 30 years, no doubt the last 10 to 12 years were most illustrious. Thanks to the present leadership of Malam Umaru Ibrahim and the entire management he is leading.

When he quits the scene, he will be leaving behind one of the strongest regulatory institutions in the country, with a reputation for disciplined, among other professional attributes. He has also contributed significantly to building an institution that is not resting on its oars in ensuring that it delivers on its core mandates of Deposit Guarantee, Bank Supervision, Distress Resolution and Liquidation and Risk Minimiser.

Its primary public policy objectives remain to contribute to financial system stability, protecting depositors and providing an orderly means of resolution and compensation in the event of bank failures. Hassan, a financial analyst, wrote from Abuja.

Jul 24, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1] View original post here[2]. A new poll from Pew Research finds that 72% of American adults think social media companies wield too much power and influence over politics. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg According to a survey conducted last week, just 22% of Americans believe Silicon Valley technocrats hold the 'right amount' of political power, while just 6% believe it's 'not enough.' Nearly 9 out of 10 'conservative Republicans' (89%) feel social media platforms have too much power vs.

74% of 'moderate or liberal Republicans,' while liberal Democrats are slightly more likely than moderate or conservative Democrats to agree (68% vs. 60%). Majorities of both Republicans and Democrats believe social media companies wield too much power, but Republicans are particularly likely to express this view. Roughly eight-in-ten Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (82%) think these companies have too much power and influence in politics, compared with 63% of Democrats and Democratic leaners. Democrats, on the other hand, are more likely than Republicans to say these companies have about the right amount of power and influence in politics (28% vs. 13%). Small shares in both parties believe these companies do not have enough power. -Pew Research[3] The results echoed a similar 2018 Center survey[4] which found that Republicans were more likely than Democrats to believe social media platforms censor political content, and are biased towards liberal views. On July 27, CEOs of Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Google will appear together in front of Congress for the first time to testify before the House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee, which has spent the last year investigating competition within the tech industry. Beyond debates about fair business practices, the tech industry has also come under fire in recent months from a host of critics - from President Donald Trump[5] to civil rights advocates[6] and even tech companies' own employees[7]. Amid these concerns, Americans favor more, not less, regulation of major technology companies, according to the Center's recent survey. Some 47% of the public thinks the government should be regulating major technology companies more than they are now, while just 11% think they should be regulated less. About four-in-ten (39%) believe regulation should stay at its current level. -Pew Research[8] Will lawmakers push for oversight so that Silicon Valley tech platforms stop discriminating along party lines? urn:contentItem:5XBB-RDP1-JBCM-F0MF-00000-00Nearly Every State Is Investigating Facebook For Potential Antitrust Violations2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:28ZLexisNexisNearly Every State Is Investigating Facebook For Potential Antitrust ViolationsRachel SandlerForbes Staff

Forty-seven state attorneys general have signed on to the case led by New York.

Topline: New York Attorney General Letitia JamesannouncedTuesday that 47 states are now investigating Facebook for possible antitrust violations, ramping up the legal pressure on the social network as bipartisan calls to break up Big Tech continue to grow.

When the investigation was first announced in September, only nine states had signed on.

Now nearly every state in the country is investigating the social media giant.

California, where Facebook is based, has not publicly said that it has joined. A spokesperson for Xavier Becerra, the state s attorney general, declined to comment.

Crucial quote: Our investigation now has the support of 47 attorneys general from around the nation, who are all concerned that Facebook may have put consumer data at risk, reduced the quality of consumers choices, and increased the price of advertising, James said in a press release.

Key background: Facebook is already facing federal antitrust investigations from the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Justice and Congress.

News peg: As tech companies grow and become an ever-present force in the lives of users, calls for Big Tech to be broken up are coming from both sides of the aisle. Regulators may be looking at Facebook s WhatsApp and Instagram acquisitions, and Facebook also faces separate criticism for facilitating the spread of misinformation and propaganda around elections.

Tangent: The scope of the multistate investigation into Facebook is similar to that of Google, which is subject to aprobefrom 50 state attorneys general.

urn:contentItem:5X15-0YD1-DY7V-G0V0-00000-00Nearly every state is now investigating Google over antitrust2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisNearly every state is now investigating Google over antitrust

Updated 3:39 pm ET -- adds quote from office of CA AG about why they haven't joined the investigation and fixes typo in headline. Updated 3:18 pm ET -- changes headline and adds details of and quotes from announcement.

By Brian Fung, CNN BusinessWASHINGTON (CNN Business)

WASHINGTON (CNN Business) -- A group of 50 attorneys general from 48 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico unveiled a major antitrust investigation of Google Monday, sharply escalating the regulatory scrutiny facing the tech giant.

The probe will focus on whether Google has harmed competition and consumers, looking at least initially into the company's conduct in its search, advertising and other businesses, though it may expand from there.

Speaking to reporters in front of the US Supreme Court Monday, a group of 13 attorneys general struck a bipartisan tone. Karl Racine, attorney general of the District of Columbia, said it was an "unusual setting" for a group that typically disagrees on issues ranging from gun control to reproductive rights.

"But we are acting as one today," he said.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton said the investigation will begin by looking at Google's advertising and search dominance but hinted that the scope of the probe could widen significantly.

"The facts will lead where the facts will lead," he said.

To kick off the probe, the states on Monday sent Google a compulsory request for information known as a civil investigative demand (CID). Officials declined to say what was contained in the request, but South Dakota Attorney General Jason Ravnsborg told CNN Business the document is dozens of pages long with many questions.

The attorneys general of California and Alabama are the only two from all 50 states not yet participating.

Asked why California has not joined the states pursuing the investigation, a spokesperson for California Attorney General Xavier Becerra said the state is committed to fighting anti-competitive behavior.

"But to protect the integrity of our work, we can't comment --- to confirm or deny any pending or potential investigation," the spokesperson said.

A spokesperson for the Alabama attorney general didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.

The investigation significantly raises the risks of regulation for Google, which so far has faced antitrust scrutiny from federal lawmakers and the Justice Department. On Friday, Google disclosed in an investor filing that it had received a CID from DOJ.

The multi-state probe is the second such look into Big Tech to be announced within a week; on Friday, eight states and the District of Columbia said they have begun an antitrust investigation into Facebook.

Dec 30, 2019( Naked Capitalism: http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/ Delivered by Newstex) By Jerri-Lynn Scofield, who has worked as a securities lawyer and a derivatives trader. She is currently writing a book about textile artisans. Some good news out of Nebraska on the right to repair. Right to repair advocates achieved some successes in 2019. The concept made the agenda for 2020 presidential campaigns, endorsed first by Elizabeth Warren and then Bernie Sanders, starting with farm equipment.

Twenty state legislatures have considered digital right to repair measures - although so fair, none has become state law. There is broader public awareness of the concept, with the New York Times editorial board now in favour. And the EU has adopted a limited right to repair for household appliances, to take effect in April 2021, with Australia, Canada, and South Africa also joining the party. Part of the impetus for these measures is the huge environmental costs of a throwaway culture, particularly for ewaste. But the economics costs are also a major concern, particularly for regulators. Both the Federal Trade Commission and the House Judiciary committee have undertaken initiatives, with the House committee questioning whether Big Tech - e.g., Amazon,Apple, Facebook, and Google - are violating anti-trust laws. Apple, a staunch right to repair opponent, adopted limited concessions in late August, to provide independent repair providers access to Apple parts and repair tools (seeApple Blinks on Right to Repair: Or Does It?[1]) Earlier in 2019, the company played a major role in defeating legislation in California (see Apple to California Legislators: Consumers Will Hurt Themselves if Provided a Right to Repair[2]). For a recap of these and other developments, see US PIRG RIGHT TO REPAIR WRAPS UP A BIG YEAR[3]).Nebraska Right to Repair for Farm Equipment In early December, the Nebraska Farm Bureau voted 176 -1, to support a right to repair, including clear guidelines to prevent diluting future agreements. This policy was to counter what was seen as an earlier capitulation in California, where the California Farm Bureau Federation accepted a half-measure that left dealers with the whip hand over most repairs. According to US PIRG in NEBRASKA FARMERS VOTE OVERWHELMINGLY FOR RIGHT TO REPAIR[4]:Working equipment is mission-critical for farms. If you can't harvest your crop because the equipment you need isn't functioning, you can't earn a living. But modern farm equipment is getting harder and harder to fix because manufacturers such as John Deere won't give farmers or independent mechanics access to what they need[5] to repair the equipment outside of their dealerships. This is especially true of the software locks on the equipment that require access to dealership-only software to fully repair. A documentary by Vice cataloged how farmers have taken to hiring hackers[6]and buying black market software to bypass the software locks so they can keep equipment in the fields.Dealers are fierce opponents of any right to repair, for as Crain's Chicago Business reports in Why Deere and Cat don't want customers to do it themselves[7],: Manufacturers have a strong financial incentive to limit customers' repair options. Making an iPhone hard to fix drives sales of new ones. For Illinois heavy-equipment makers, controlling repairs drives lucrative service work to dealers and boosts sales of parts, a growing portion of manufacturers' revenues. 'From the perspective of [John] Deere, opening up controlled systems or applications on equipment presents nothing but downsides,' says Morningstar analyst Scott Pope.Dealers depend on repair work, which yields profit margins up to five times better than new-equipment sales, Pope says. Right-to-repair laws also threaten parts sales, since Deere generally sells parts to its dealers. Deere brought in $37.36 billion in revenue in 2018, with about $5.8 billion from parts sales. Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Christopher Ciolino says Deere's parts sales are growing faster than equipment sales. 'There has been a concerted effort to grow the aftermarket business' among all heavy-equipment makers, Ciolino says. 'Parts and service have very attractive margin profiles that not only add to the bottom line but help mitigate the cyclicality in their business.' Nebraska farmers are now aggressively promoting specific standards according to US PIRG in NEBRASKA FARMERS VOTE OVERWHELMINGLY FOR RIGHT TO REPAIR[8]:The measure adopted by the Nebraska Farm Bureau laid out specific standards for any agreement or legislation:Right to Repair: Nebraska Farm Bureau supports the implementation of comprehensive right to repair legislation OR a negotiated written agreement between ag producers and original equipment manufacturers (OEMs). This legislation or agreement must: 1. Be enforceable. 2. Guarantee farmer/repair technician access to the identical information, parts, and tools that are available to dealerships. These items must be fairly and reasonably priced (taking into account both small and large producers) and be delivered in a timely manner. 3. Include ALL OEM equipment, regardless of age, model, or years in use at the time of the effective date. 4. Differentiate between repair (the restoration of hardware to its original intended function) and illegal 'modding,' (modification of original hardware to bypass environmental controls). 5. Not require any agricultural equipment owner to agree to any contract which removes existing rights. Furthermore, Nebraska Farm Bureau will support or endorse any legislation or agreement that grants agricultural equipment owners/repair shops with the same rights accorded to automobile ...ght truck owners/repair shops. The Nebraska Farm Bureau is currently attempting to negotiate a right to repair deal with dealers and original equipment manufacturers, to incorporate these minimum standards, according to NET in Nebraska Farm Bureau Eager For 'Right To Repair' Agreement In 2020 [9].If a deal is not achieved by this time next year, the Nebraska farmers will opt to pursue mandatory legislation instead. Presidential campaigns provide an opportunity to highlight policies that affect farmers. In 2020, one key issue is the right to repair for farm equipment.https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2019/12/nebraska-farmers-lead-on-right-to-repair.html?utm_source=feedburner..._medium=feed..._campaign=Feed:+NakedCapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29# This entry was posted in Doomsday scenarios[10], Global warming[11], Guest Post[12], Regulations and regulators[13] on December 30, 2019[14] by Jerri-Lynn Scofield[15]. 1 Heathrow will announce plans for an extra 25,000 flights a year to increase capacity before the opening of a third runway. The airport, the biggest in Europe, wants to accommodate additional take-offs and landings, equivalent to 68 a day, within the next few years. The plans will be outlined in a public consultation next week.

Page 4 2 Once famed for the Wedgwood and Royal Doulton potteries, Burslem, one of the six towns that make up the city of Stoke-on-Trent in Staffordshire, is now the holder of a more unfortunate claim to fame. A third of shops in its small centre stand empty, some for five years or more, which is the highest percentage in the UK, according to research by the Local Data Company. Page 20 3 Wall Street surged as a bumper jobs report and soothing comments from the chairman of the US Federal Reserve put a shine on a turbulent week for trading. Jerome Powell said that the central bank was "listening sensitively" to stock markets after December's sell-off and would be "patient" with its interest rate policy. Page 43 4 House prices are rising at their weakest pace in six years after uncertainty created by Brexit talks led to a "noticeable slowdown" in December, according to Nationwide. Growth was only 0.5 per cent last month, down from 1.9 per cent in November and the slowest rate since February 2013. Page 43 5 Herb Kelleher, the co-founder of Southwest Airlines whose low-fare business model changed the aviation industry and was shamelessly aped by Ryanair, has died aged 87. Page 43 6 With Apple struggling to shift its iPhones, Facebook battling a string of scandals and investors chipping away at the valuations of Amazon, Netflix and Google, it feels as though Big Tech is in a rut - yet Microsoft is bucking the trend.

7 Activity in Britain's dominant services sector picked up in December, but businesses remained downbeat as confidence fell to its second lowest level since the financial crisis, according to a survey of executives. Page 46 8 TSB has failed to publish the first part of a long-awaited report into its calamitous IT meltdown. The delay past its planned date of Christmas may provoke fresh criticism of the bank by MPs, including Nicky Morgan, chairwoman of the Treasury select committee. Page 47 9 Gear4music, Britain's biggest online seller of instruments and musical equipment, suffered a crushing one-day share price fall after it issued a profit warning despite stellar sales over Christmas. Page 48 10Ofgem, the energy regulator, has threatened to shut down Economy Energy, a household supplier with 250,000 customers, unless it addresses service failings. Page 49

urn:contentItem:5W36-HS61-DXH2-6097-00000-00Negotiations Continue between U.S. and China over Trade Deal; U.S. Navy Releases Video of Ships Moving Through Suez Canal toward Iran; Rudy Giuliani Discusses Deal with Former Vice President Biden's Son and Ukraine Energy Company; President Trump Sees Uptick in Job Approval Polling; Iranian Threat; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; War of Words; Live Free or Biden; Russia Connection; Ready to Launch; Safe Injection Sites; Breaking Up is Hard to Do2019-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisFOX SPECIAL REPORT WITH BRET BAIER6:00 PM ESTByron York, Mollie Hemingway, Jeff MasonNEWSDomestic051001cb.254Negotiations Continue between U.S. and China over Trade Deal; U.S. Navy Releases Video of Ships Moving Through Suez Canal toward Iran; Rudy Giuliani Discusses Deal with Former Vice President Biden's Son and Ukraine Energy Company; President Trump Sees Uptick in Job Approval Polling; Iranian Threat; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; War of Words; Live Free or Biden; Russia Connection; Ready to Launch; Safe Injection Sites; Breaking Up is Hard to DoBret Baier, Gillian Turner, Susan Li, Jennifer Griffin, John Roberts, Catherine Herridge, Mike Emanuel, Rich Edson, Greg Palkot, Dan Springer

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS CHIEF POLITICAL ANCHOR: This is a Fox News alert. I'm Bret Baier in Washington.

We begin tonight with a new indication of just how seriously President Trump and his national security team are taking what have been called credible warnings about threats from Iran. We learned about an hour ago the U.S. is sending an additional war ship and Patriot missile battery to the Middle East, adding to the forces already heading that way.

National security correspondent Jennifer Griffin has breaking details tonight from the Pentagon. Good evening -- Jennifer.

JENNIFER GRIFFIN, FOX NEWS NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT: Good evening - - Bret.

Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan has approved the deployment of a Patriot missile battery to the Middle East as the administration tries to ramp up pressure on Iran which it says is prepositioning missiles that could threaten U.S. forces across the Middle East.

A Patriot battery is an air defense system with roughly 100 missiles. They can shoot down ballistic missiles and aircraft. The Pentagon also announced tonight it's moving an amphibious war ship from Europe, the USS Arlington, which transports U.S. Marines, amphibious vehicles, and rotary aircraft to support amphibious assault or expeditionary warfare missions.

The Arlington is replacing another U.S. warship in a swap. These military assets will join the USS Abraham Lincoln carrier strike group and a U.S. Air Force bomber task force.

In a statement just released by the Pentagon, the Department of Defense continues to closely monitor the activities of the Iranian regime, the military and proxies, adding the United States does not seek conflict with Iran, but we are postured and ready to defend U.S. forces and interests in the region -- Bret.

BAIER: Jennifer -- thank you. The breaking details, we'll come back for any more information.

There is still no deal tonight between the U.S. and China on a new trade policy. President Trump raised the stakes overnight, increasing tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports. China is promising to retaliate. All this comes as negotiators suspend their talks for at least now aimed at reaching a compromise that could end an escalating trade dispute between the two most powerful economies on the planet.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts has that story from the north lawn. Good evening -- John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret -- good evening to you.

Administration officials tell Fox News that no more talks are currently scheduled between the United States and China, but there is still optimism that a deal can eventually be reached.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: The 11th round of trade talks between the U.S. And China came and went with no hint of an agreement. But President Trump indicating that the talks will continue. The President tweeting, "Over the course of the past two days, the United States and China have held candid and constructive of conversations on the status of the trade relationship between both countries. The relationship between President Xi and myself remains a very strong one and conversations into the future will continue."

After China indicated it was taking back some core items of a deal it had already agreed to, President Trump lit a fire under the Chinese leadership. This morning raising tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods from 10 percent to 25 percent, tariffs the President said may or may not be removed depending on what happens with respect to future negotiations.

China's chief negotiator, the Vice Premier Liu He said today's talks went fairly well adding that talks will continue. But he criticized President Trump's use of tariffs to put the squeeze on China.

LIU HE, CHINESE VICE PREMIER (through translator): China believes raising tariffs in the current situation is not a solution to the problem but harmful to China, to the United States, and to the whole world.

ROBERTS: President Trump also upped the ante this morning, tweeting that the process has begun to place additional tariffs at 25 percent on the remaining $325 billion in Chinese goods. That would be the largest tranche of tariffs yet, a big stick to wield.

Support for the President's tariff strategy is mixed. Brian Duncan, a hog farmer in Illinois says he stands to lose a lot from Chinese retaliation.

BRIAN DUNCAN, HOG FARMER: It prolongs what we hope would be a short, brief trade war into something that now looks indefinite. And it will directly impact all of agriculture. Not just hog farmers, but all of agriculture's bottom line.

ROBERTS: But even some Democratic lawmakers say America can't allow the status quo to continue.

REP. DEBBIE DINGELL (D), MICHIGAN: We don't have a playing field in this country and we have to have fair trade policies, because quite frankly it's been hurting the American worker.

ROBERTS: President Trump has promised to use money derived from U.S. tariffs to buy U.S. agricultural goods and send them to countries in need, but many companies simply pass the cost on to consumers.

The pro-business group Americans for Prosperity today urging the President to choose another path in a statement saying "Countless families, factory workers, and farmers are feeling the financial strain caused by continued trade escalation."

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: While not coming out today in favor of tariffs, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce today stood with the President's attempts to renegotiate the U.S.-China trade relationship. The Chamber of Commers saying It is deeply concerned by indications that China is backing away from progress already made -- Bret.

BAIER: John Roberts live on the north lawn. John -- thanks.

The Dow recovered from 358 points down at one point today to finish ahead 114. The S&O 500 was up 11. The Nasdaq gained 6. For the week, the Dow and the S&P 500 lost more than two percentage points. The Nasdaq was down three.

The federal government recorded a $160.3 billion surplus in April. Revenues for the month jumped to an all-time high. But even with a flood of tax receipts, the deficit so far this year is running 37.7 percent higher than a year ago. The administration expects this year's deficit to be $1.1 trillion.

House Ways and Means committee chairman Democrat Richard Neal has issued subpoenas to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Internal Revenue Service commissioner Charles Rettig over their refusal to provide six years of tax returns for President Trump. The White House so far is refusing to comment.

urn:contentItem:5TJ3-VK81-JBJ7-N1HG-00000-00Neobank Revolut to launch in Australia2018-10-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisNeobank Revolut to launch in AustraliaJames Eyers

The fastest growing unicorn in Europe is coming to Australia with 20,000 on its waiting list. Its first product? A pre-paid debit card.

"I never want Revolut to be referring to itself as a bank," says its head of marketing, Chad West. "We are an alternative to a bank. We are completely different."

Revolut, headquartered in London, was only founded three years ago; it now has over 3 million customers in Europe, a number that has doubled over the past nine months.

The neobank is attracting 7000 new customers each day, and expects this will be 10,000 by the end of this year.

In April it secured $US250 million in fresh venture capital funding for global expansion, at a valuation of $US1.7 billion. It's the fastest-growing unicorn tech company in Europe.

And according to its website, Revolut is about to land down under. Ominously for the major banks, without any advertising, 20,000 Australians have already signed up to its waiting list.

Revolut expects to have a prepaid debit card live in the Australian market by the end of the year. It will launch in the new year and is targeting 150,000 local users by the end of 2019.

It's also taking on New Zealand, part of an ambitious plan to also capture Millennial customers in the United States, Canada, Hong Kong and Singapore.

Mr West reckons timing for the Australian launch is solid. The loss of trust in the big four banks on the back of the Hayne commission should help it lure customers away from the incumbents, he says.

"When we launch in Australia, our main goal is to be an alternative to traditional banks. We are very anti bank, and people have really resonated with that," Mr West says in an exclusive interview with The Australian Financial Review from London, ahead of an appearance at the Intersekt Festival in Melbourne on Monday, October 29, where he is delivering a keynote address.

Revolut's arrival will also worry other budding neobanks in Australia, such as Volt, Xinja and 86 400, which are also trying to lure Millennials away from the big four. The rise of "challenger banks" will be discussed at this week's Sibos conference in Sydney.

Revolut has already secured the necessary licensing in Australia for its payments cards by piggybacking off an AFSL licence held by an existing bank that Mr West declined to name.

It plans to use the new start-up bank licensing regime established by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and become an "authorised deposit-taking institution" (ADI), which would allow it to take deposits.

The company operates current accounts in Europe under an "e-money" licence, and is close to secure a full banking licence there which will allow it to begin lending operations. It plans to offer personal loans, business loans and mortgages, a product suite it also wants to replicate in Australia.

But the first product will be payments cards - which could let it get between existing banks and their customer relationships. Apple Pay should be available soon after launch, allowing customers to pay with their iPhones and Apple Watches, something only ANZ offers among the big four.

Revolut built up its big customer numbers in Europe by providing an ultra-low cost foreign exchange options for travellers. Its cards have no fees for overseas withdrawals and transfers, and exchange rates are the same banks get in wholesale markets. This will also be the case in Australia, where the competition regulator recently launched an investigation targeting the high costs of money transfers offered by major banks. It is also offering low-cost share trading, insurance and cryptocurrency wallets.

Revolut was also able to scale because its banking application was better than those offered by the British and European incumbents - something that will be harder in Australia, given the big tech investment by the majors on their banking applications. Mr West agrees Australian banks "are certainly better than UK banks and most European banks". But he adds "they are still nothing special".

"None of them are offering the real, in depth analytics we are offering on spending, none are even close on the FX spreads, none of them have an app designed as beautifully as ours."

Revolut has aspirations to become the "Amazon of finance". Pressed to explain, Mr West says customers don't want half-a-dozen apps on their phone managing different elements of their financial life. "They want to have everything centralised in one brand they know that they trust.

"Customer are becoming lazy and expecting more from the services they use. I don't want my bank to bombard me with offers. I want to give my bank my criteria and to give me one solution right to me that matches my criteria."

The philosophy of Revolut is much more tech than fin. "We are a tech company first and foremost. We are redefining banking on a global scale," he says.

Its recent Series C capital raising round - one of the largest ever by a European tech company - was led by DST Global, which was an early investor in Facebook and Spotify. It was also supported by Index Ventures, in investor in Facebook, Coinbase and Robinhood; and Ribbit Capital, one of the best-known VC investors in Palo Alto.

Like Netflix and Spotify, Revolut is pushing towards a subscription-based model: it has 150,000 customers paying ??6.99 a month; and 80,000 paying ??12.99 a month. These include all-you-can-eat insurance deals, personal concierges and various cashback offers. And like Uber and Amazon, Revolut has no plans to become profitable any time soon.

Mr West says Revolut doesn't consider banks its main competition - rather, it will come from Facebook and Amazon "when they inevitably break into finance". Oozing confidence, he says "with our capital, brand awareness and unique style marketing, we won't struggle to win the Australian market over.

"I am convinced we can do it faster and better than any other fintech in the market."

Time will tell.

Mr West says Revolut doesn`t consider banks its main competition rather, it will come from Facebook and Amazon "when they inevitably break into finance". Oozing confidence, he says "with our capital, brand awareness and unique style marketing, we won`t struggle to win the Australian market over.

"I am convinced we can do it faster and better than any other fintech in the market."

Time will tell. 2018 Global Data Point.

urn:contentItem:5V7X-58J1-JBJ7-N3W4-00000-00Neobanks to spur big four into reaction2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisNeobanks to spur big four into reactionJames Eyers

All of the major banks have watched the impressive growth of Afterpay and are jittery that new start-up banks could disrupt customer relationships.

Each of the big four banks have considered launching new digital bank brands to attract new, young, digital-savvy customers. Apart from National Australia Bank's UBank, the plans have been non-starters, getting lost among layers of bureaucracy, management changes and restrictions on new investment.

But the pending launch of Volt Bank, which on Tuesday received an unrestricted banking licence from the prudential regulator, and with Up already in the market, the majors might be forced to reconsider whether creating entirely new standalone digital brands, or partnering with emerging players in the emerging "neobank" space, is needed to stay on the front foot in the fast-moving world of digital banking.

NAB is increasing investment in UBank, but it's not considered a   neobank, a term that's being used to describe standalone, start-up banks built from the ground up on new technology platforms designed for use over smartphones. (UBank runs on NAB legacy technology systems and its management reports into the NAB mothership.)

In the UK, some of the major banks are moving aggressively to counter the disruptive threat from the likes of Monzo and Revolut, new brands that are starting to attract a material number of customers. (The five largest neobanks in the UK have 2.5 million customers, quadrupling over the last year.)

Royal Bank of Scotland is creating a new digital banking brand, to be known as Bo, that will be run independently of RBS. Management is keen to migrate 1 million NatWest customers on to the new platform.

It's earlier days in Australia. But Up, which is operating under Bendigo and Adelaide Bank's licence, is acquiring 1000 new customers each week to its new savings account, which is offering an introductory interest rate of 2.75 per cent. About 22,000 accounts have been opened since its October launch.

Volt will launch its savings and transaction card products from March. It hasn't yet announced pricing but has big ambitions to lure big four customers with higher interest rates.

Other local challengers including 86 400 and Xinja are awaiting licences.

While none of the new players are likely to move the dial on the billions of dollars sitting in deposits in the major banks (Commonwealth Bank has almost $500 billion in deposits), they won't need to scale at a lightning pace to make the majors jittery.

All of the major banks have watched the impressive growth of Afterpay, which has attracted more than 2 million (mostly) Millennial customers in quick time. They're aware the royal commission has tarnished trust in their traditional brands built up over decades.

The majors fear the new players could interpose themselves between customer relationships by offering a slick new experience that might render the incumbents to utilities in the background. This could become a bigger disruptive threat down the track under the government's open banking policies which could facilitate more customer account switching.

Plenty of false starts

The Australian Financial Review understands various majors have actively considered moving into the space in the past few years. ANZ Banking Group was apparently considering unveiling a new digital bank in Asia before Shayne Elliott was appointed CEO, but abandoned the plans when it decided to refocus on Australia.

However, it is believed ANZ has been talking to Revolut, one of the biggest neobanks in the UK, as a potential partner in Australia.

Commonwealth Bank experimented with South African digital bank TYME but abandoned efforts to roll this out more broadly. However, industry sources consider it possible CBA could make a new digital play either via an acquisition or the development of a new brand.

Similarly, Westpac Banking Corp has also considered building a new digital banking brand but decided not to proceed when funding was allocated to re-engineering of its own banking systems. But its venture-capital fund Reinventure has been acquiring capability in the digital banking space and could provide the platform for a new push.

Management consultants are talking to global banks about the need for new, "greenfield" investments, as opposed to thinking about technology developments via user experience improvement.

Oliver Wyman issued its annual State of the financial services industry report on Tuesday, titled It's time to start again.

"Experience has shown that by following a greenfield approach it is possible to build a digital banking or insurance platform that is open to customers in just 12 months, at materially lower cost than in the past," Oliver Wyman said.

"Greenfield lets you sidestep the challenge of legacy infrastructure and get to a truly customer-centric offering faster."

Separate brand

Mark Bailie, the CEO of Bo, which is being managed as a separate brand within the RBS portfolio, says the core challenge "is maintaining customer engagement in a world where the big tech firms are building powerful customer relationships, there are lots of competitors emerging, the barriers to entry are falling, and technology is ever more flexible and powerful".

The start-ups are putting customer-centric design at the heart of their operations. Volt said on Tuesday it's creating Volt Labs, an app-based online community that lets customers provide their insights and ideas to contribute to designing Volt Bank products and services. Monzo did a similar thing in the UK.

Given their market power, the majors might decide on a wait-and-see approach. After all, there are plenty of unanswered questions about the neobanks, including their ability to raise capital, the cost of acquiring new customers and the tough road to profitability.

But UK neobanks are starting to grow via viral marketing and word of mouth. Up is already in the top 10 finance apps in Australia and is conducting marketing on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter for customer acquisition. Oliver Wyman estimates it will cost a digital bank $30 to acquire a new current customer on average, compared to $150 for incumbents.

The start-ups are also investing in distribution partnerships. For example, Up is working with Afterpay and Google. Volt has partnered with PayPal and Collection House. And in the future, neobanks could seek to team up with retailers, telecommunication companies or airlines, who might use a combination of open banking and the newly licensed start-ups to increase their exposure to financial services.

urn:contentItem:5J41-1VJ1-JDK3-949P-00000-00NEO changes the listing landscape2016-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:29ZLexisNexisINVESTINGNEO changes the listing landscape

New National Stock Exchange announcement of first listing brings competition to marketplace.

The Aequitas NEO Exchange( https://aequitasneoexchange.com/en/ ) took another significant step in its evolution last month with the announcement of its first listing application; a development that shows that the innovative new stock exchange is a viable competitor to the Toronto Stock Exchange.

Invesco Canada Ltd. plans to list its newest exchange traded fund, the Power-Shares DWA Global Momentum Index ETF, on the NEO Exchange. The ETF is expected to begin trading in March once regulatory approval is granted.

The PowerShares listing is a milestone for the new exchange as it nears the first anniversary of its launch, and represents something of a statement on the part of Invesco Canada, says its president, Peter Intraligi.

"Philosophically, the idea of increasing competition in Canada makes a great deal of sense to us. We are always looking for ways to be more efficient with our Power-Shares ETF listings and are strong proponents of the notion that increased competition drives efficiency and innovation (Invesco is one of the shareholders of Aequitas Innovations Inc.( http://aequitasinnovations.com/ ), the parent company of the NEO Exchange.)

As a shareholder the company has been able to closely monitor the growth of NEO since its launch, and with the development of the Powershares Global Momentum Index ETF, determined that the time was right to list on the exchange.

It was not a decision Invesco took lightly despite its ownership stake in in the parent company, Intraligi says. "Clearly, the No. 1 and most important priority is the investors who invest in your products. You want to make sure that there aren't going to be any issues or flaws, and operationally we are very satisfied with where NEO is. We are very comfortable now with the position of the exchange."

Having made the first move, the Invesco president expects others to follow.

"Every issuer would subscribe to the idea that more competition is better. I think the challenge was getting to the level of comfort you need to be the first to support something new. It is the old story of, 'I don't want to be first, just in case.' For us, we feel very comfortable and we hope that when our listing goes live it sends a clear signal that NEO is ready to bring a new level of competitiveness to the market, competition which benefits everyone."

Intraligi says that his company has already received "very positive" comments from broker-dealer market makers. "They would like to see more competition. When you look at the U.S. market, that (competition) does exist and you get greater efficiencies and economies."

In Canada currently, all ETFs are traded on just one exchange. "So I think this makes sense and we hope that this does start to broaden the market."

Brent Holliday, chief executive and founder of Vancouver-based Garibaldi Capital Advisors, is hopeful that the new exchange will prove to be a more cost-effective and efficient way for Canadian firms to go public.

"If NEO does something in the senior listings space along the lines of what AIM (the London Stock Exchange market for smaller companies) did, and offers the liquidity and benefits like better pricing to companies, it might be a great alternative for growing tech companies."

To list in the Canadian Market you didn't have a choice. But now you do.

Currently such companies have few options, he adds. "The complaint against the TSX is that it is really a resource and financial service market and so if you see big tech companies in the U.S. and other markets, they don't think of the TSX as a place to go list their companies.

Similarly, large Canadian tech companies that are thinking about going public, if they have U.S. equity investors, they look to the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange and then think of only the TSX as a colist."

Tim Johnston, chief listings officer of the NEO Exchange, is bullish on NEO's opportunities in the listing space. The exchange launched its listings business in the middle of 2015, so "to get your first listing just six or seven months after your launch is quite remarkable given everything involved in the process." says Johnston.

Related

Incentive high for companies to move from TSX to NEO( http://wp.me/p1SCTv-2Euk )

Monumental year for new exchange( http://business.financialpost.com/investing/monumental-year-for-new-exchange )

"The first listing is an important catalyst because it gets over that kind of resistance to being the first, and in the Canadian market, from a senior issuer's perspective, there really hasn't been an alternative to the TSX in our market before."

Michael Becker, executive vice-president international business strategy, with New York-based Business Wire and a NEO trusted service provider, understands the David-and-Goliath challenge the upstart exchange is facing.

"You are fighting tremendous incumbent inertia, a lack of innovation and battling the status quo," he says, noting the landscape is ripe for a lower-cost and more innovative alternative.

"If you are a Canadian company looking to list on a senior exchange in the Canadian market you didn't have a choice. But now you do."
